oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stereocard of Memphis Exhibit, Negro Building, Atlanta Exposition, 1895
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A stereocard depicting the Memphis Exhibit for the Negro Building at the 1895 Atlanta Exposition. Pictured are four African Americans, two women and two men, in an interior setting. The words Shelby County Tennessee can be seen in the upper right corner of the frames. The Memphis Exhibit was organized by Julia Britton Hooks of Memphis, Tennessee. Julia Britton Hooks, an African American clubwoman known as the ""Angel of Beale Street,"" was born free in 1852 in Frankfort, Kentucky. Hooks was a charter member of the Memphis chapter of the NAACP and was the grandmother of the national director of the organization, Benjamin J. Hooks. Julia Hooks became a leader in African American cultural and educational affairs, and participant in the suffrage movement. A stereocard is depictions of the same image from two different angles, that when placed in a stereoscope make the image appear three dimensional.

The Atlanta Exposition was controversial in the African American community, and national leaders Ida B. Wells and Fredrick Douglass encouraged African Americans not to participate. At the Atlanta Exposition, Booker T. Washington delivered the famous Atlanta Compromise speech and laid a proposed foundation for race relations in the Southern United States. African Americans would submit to white political rule in exchange for basic education, due process of law, and economic stability. This included not making demands for the right to vote.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cotton States Exposition (1895 : Atlanta, Ga.)
